clinical_study.brief_title: Increasing Physical Activity Among Sedentary Older Adults:What, Where, When, and With Whom
clinical_study.official_title: Increasing Physical Activity Among Sedentary Older Adults:What, Where, When, and With Whom

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to develop a smart phone/tablet app to administer a behavior change program that helps adults to increase daily steps by planning where, when, and with whom to walk. The investigators will test the effectiveness of various components of the walking program app for increasing the number of daily steps among sedentary older adults. The investigators also will examine the effects on self-efficacy and social integration/support.

detailed_description.textblock:
Physical activity is broadly beneficial for physical, psychological, and cognitive aspects of health. Yet, only one in five U.S. adults meets the CDC physical activity guidelines. Making physical activity accessible and feasible throughout life is an important public health policy objective that is within reach with the right kind of behavioral and environmental supports. The project aims to provide such supports for an active lifestyle thereby contributing to healthy aging.The goal of this project is to increase physical activity (i.e., walking) in sedentary older adults by providing the environmental and behavioral resources to incorporate additional steps into their daily lives. The investigators will use a behavioral approach that fosters a sense of control and facilitates planning by focusing on the what, when, where, and with whom. The investigators propose a user-friendly practical way to increase steps. With specific tailored information about number of steps and distance as a function of time available, participants can plan when, where, and with whom they will be able to obtain the desired number of steps, break goals into manageable portions (at different times throughout the day or week), and thereby increase the likelihood of goal achievement.
During the App development phase the investigators will demonstrate the App to 5 to 10 older adults to get their input. The goal will be to get their feedback about the App features and to make sure it is user friendly. The investigators will ask questions about the ease of using the App and their understanding of the App features. The interviewer will record their answers to share with the research team and App developer. Modifications to the App will be made as needed.
The investigators will test which components of the program are most successful for increasing step counts. The four components of the app can be administered together or separately. There are two possible designs for this study, depending on the timing and resources available. In the first option, 30 participants will be randomly assigned to three conditions: the accelerometer program alone,the accelerometer with the schedule and maps, and the accelerometer with the schedule and maps along with the social network component. It is predicted that the complete four component program will be most effective. In the second option, which will be implemented if time and resources do not allow for the three group design, 20 older adults will be recruited and all of them will be given the same condition that involves all four components of the App. In this case the investigators will look at whether there is improvement in steps over time, but the different App conditions will not be compared.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All conditions will receive the App for use on a smart phone. The control group will just have the accelerometer program to set step goals and to count steps. One experimental condition will have the accelerometer to set goals and count steps in addition to the schedule and map components. And the second experimental group will have the accelerometer to set goals and count steps, along with the schedule, map, and social components.
study_design_info.masking_description: The participants are aware of the nature of the App features they are given. They are not aware of whether they are in an experimental or control condition.

primary_outcome.description: Number of steps recorded daily on the phone app

secondary_outcome.description: Amount of confidence in ability to exercise
Amount of perceived control over exercise
Number of virtual interactions with other caregivers using the exergame

arm_group.description: The control group will just have the App with the accelerometer program to set step goals and to count and record steps for 3 months.
Experimental condition 1 will set steps goals and have the schedule and map components.
Experimental condition 2 will set step goals and have the schedule, map, and social components.

intervention.description: This group will be given the App with the accelerometer to count steps, the daily schedule, and walking maps. It involves setting step goals and the use of an accelerometer to calibrate number of steps to distance and time using an individual's gait, and to provide step counts. (2) There will be an interface with map programs to create walking routes for work, home, and in new locations when traveling, based on how much time is available to walk. (3) They will use a daily planner to determine when they can walk and for how long. They will use the App for 3 months.

This group will be given the same App as condition 1 with the accelerometer and step counter, daily schedule, and walking maps. In addition, the social contacts component will be added. This feature will link friends, co-workers, or neighbors in one's walk contact list to find out if someone is available to walk at a given time. They will use the App for 3 months.
This group will just receive the accelerometer program to set daily step goals and to count steps. They will monitor their steps over a 3-month period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Sedentary adults, who own a smart phone.
- Participants must be fit enough to walk for at least 20 minutes at a time.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cognitive impairment
- A recent (within the past 6 months) cardiovascular event, or fall.
- Anyone who already exercises regularly, 3 times a week or more for at least 30 minutes will be excluded.
